title: HTML entities are not decoded
description: I'll suggest to evaluate a decoding of html entities. E.g. I have a category in Wordpress whose name is "> something". The '>' char is stored on the db by Wordpress as '>' and when I query the plugin, I still get '>'. However JSON is not HTML, and probably the use of HTML entities is not good. I suggest to use html_entity_decode() on category names, slugs and so on.
text_for_topic_modeling: html entities decoded suggest evaluate decoding html entities category wordpress whose name something char stored wordpress query plugin still get however json html probably use html entities good suggest use html entity decode category names slugs
combined_text: HTML entities are not decoded I'll suggest to evaluate a decoding of html entities. E.g. I have a category in Wordpress whose name is "> something". The '>' char is stored on the db by Wordpress as '>' and when I query the plugin, I still get '>'. However JSON is not HTML, and probably the use of HTML entities is not good. I suggest to use html_entity_decode() on category names, slugs and so on.

title: /posts endpoint ignores context=edit parameter
description: Assuming: - a custom post type of `my_custom_type` - several custom fields like `a_custom_field` and `b_custom_field` The following endpoint doesn't include the custom fields in the meta data:  /posts?type=my_custom_type&context=edit  Unless I'm misunderstanding the docs, the `/posts` endpoint should include custom meta data. The custom fields meta data **is** included when I try the following:  /posts/19?context=edit

title: WP_REST_Request:get_params()/get_param() returns route
description: Not sure if this was intended, but it's annoying me. In my callback, where `$request` is `WP_REST_Request` object and I do this: $params = $request->get_params(); $zero = $request->get_param( 0 ); I get a 0 index in `$params` and `$zero` has the route URL. I don't see why it should be a param, it's not registered on the endpoint, and its redundant to what I can get with the `get_url_params()` method.
text_for_topic_modeling: rest get params get param returns route sure intended annoying callback rest object params get params zero get param get index params zero route url see param registered endpoint redundant get get url params method
combined_text: WP_REST_Request:get_params()/get_param() returns route Not sure if this was intended, but it's annoying me. In my callback, where `$request` is `WP_REST_Request` object and I do this: $params = $request->get_params(); $zero = $request->get_param( 0 ); I get a 0 index in `$params` and `$zero` has the route URL. I don't see why it should be a param, it's not registered on the endpoint, and its redundant to what I can get with the `get_url_params()` method.

title: GET request for media files results in an empty array
description: Hi I have been trying to fetch all the media files from the REST API using restangular, but no matter how I try it fails, so I decided to test the media endpoint via PostMan app and realized that although I can see the media files json object in my browsers when I browse to /wp-json/wp/v2/media but using PostMan or using restangular it always results in an empty array. The funny part is that during the time I was pulling my hair for getting the media files, the files showed up only once, and after one refresh they were gone forever, this could be a bug in the wp rest plugin.

title: Taxonomy term IDs not the same as what Wordpress actually wants?
description: I'm seeing some very strange behavior when creating and then associating terms via the REST API: - The API will create the new term as requested and return a well-formed response including the new term ID. - Attempting to associate the new term using the returned ID to an existing post will succeed as well (HTTP 201). - However, when viewing the post in WP-Admin, some of the term associations are either missing or entirely wrong. What's really strange is that I can import a term via the API and then go search for it in WP-Admin as well. The ID that I got back in my REST response is NOT the term ID that Wordpress is using to render the Edit form for the term. That seems a red flag to me, but I'm not sure how or why it's happening. Attached are screenshots of importing the term, associating the term, searching for the term against the REST API -- these are all in agreement with each other. ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 50 26 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634836/5c4406b4-27d7-11e5-8569-b9565d331183.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 2 05 33 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634838/697a5b80-27d7-11e5-9775-fd90a95aa364.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 2 19 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634851/fc4c0ff8-27d7-11e5-88a8-08f046b292e3.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 53 00 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634840/784d96f4-27d7-11e5-9c90-78514d77fd95.png) The last two screenshots are from the WP-Admin, and they clearly show that "Women's Tennis" is not associated to the Post, and the term ID is also different (27564 != 27580). ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 56 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634841/7cb7723c-27d7-11e5-8371-cb4e8fb09216.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 56 52 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634842/7fa41388-27d7-11e5-8bad-7dfa14c07241.png) Any idea what's going wrong here?
text_for_topic_modeling: taxonomy term ids wordpress actually wants seeing strange behavior creating associating terms via rest api api create new term requested return well formed response including new term attempting associate new term returned existing post succeed well http however viewing post admin term associations either missing entirely wrong really strange import term via api search admin well got back rest response term wordpress render edit form term seems red flag sure happening attached screenshots importing term associating term searching term rest api agreement screen shot https cloud githubusercontent assets png screen shot https cloud githubusercontent assets png screen shot https cloud githubusercontent assets png screen shot https cloud githubusercontent assets png last two screenshots admin clearly show women tennis associated post term also different screen shot https cloud githubusercontent assets png screen shot https cloud githubusercontent assets bad dfa png idea going wrong

What's really strange is that I can import a term via the API and then go search for it in WP-Admin as well. The ID that I got back in my REST response is NOT the term ID that Wordpress is using to render the Edit form for the term. That seems a red flag to me, but I'm not sure how or why it's happening. Attached are screenshots of importing the term, associating the term, searching for the term against the REST API -- these are all in agreement with each other. ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 50 26 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634836/5c4406b4-27d7-11e5-8569-b9565d331183.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 2 05 33 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634838/697a5b80-27d7-11e5-9775-fd90a95aa364.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 2 19 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634851/fc4c0ff8-27d7-11e5-88a8-08f046b292e3.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 53 00 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634840/784d96f4-27d7-11e5-9c90-78514d77fd95.png) The last two screenshots are from the WP-Admin, and they clearly show that "Women's Tennis" is not associated to the Post, and the term ID is also different (27564 != 27580). ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 56 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634841/7cb7723c-27d7-11e5-8371-cb4e8fb09216.png) ![screen shot 2015-07-11 at 1 56 52 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/643118/8634842/7fa41388-27d7-11e5-8bad-7dfa14c07241.png) Any idea what's going wrong here?

title: Multiple errors via param validation should be programmatically readable
description: Currently if a request contains multiple invalid request args, we compile an error string showing all the issues. However, we don't pass all the different fields that errored. From @rmccue in slack: > `new WP_Error( 'json_missing_field', 'Missing $field', array( 'key' => $field ) )` > Would output as `[ { "code": "json_missing_field", "message": "Missing abc", "data": { "key": "abc" } }]`
text_for_topic_modeling: multiple errors via param validation programmatically readable currently contains multiple invalid args compile string showing issues however pass different fields errored rmccue slack new json missing field missing field array key field would output json missing field message missing abc data key abc
combined_text: Multiple errors via param validation should be programmatically readable Currently if a request contains multiple invalid request args, we compile an error string showing all the issues. However, we don't pass all the different fields that errored. From @rmccue in slack: > `new WP_Error( 'json_missing_field', 'Missing $field', array( 'key' => $field ) )` > Would output as `[ { "code": "json_missing_field", "message": "Missing abc", "data": { "key": "abc" } }]`

title: API incompatible with setup_postdata
description: Hello, Using this API and setting up the results with `setup_postdata()` again in another WordPress site creates incompatibility issues on the following properties: `post_author` versus `author` `post_date` versus `date` `post_content` versus `content` `post_title` versus `title` This means that `the_title()`, `the_content()`, etc will not work anymore. I can understand the desire to change these ancient property names to something that makes sense but it breaks compatibility with very standard WordPress functions which most people expect to work. We fixed our problem by filtering `json_prepare_post` and assigning the properties. Related closed issue. https://github.com/WP-API/WP-API/issues/41
text_for_topic_modeling: api incompatible setup postdata hello api setting results setup postdata another wordpress site creates incompatibility issues following properties post versus post date versus date post content versus content post title versus title means title content etc work anymore understand desire ancient property names something makes sense breaks compatibility standard wordpress functions people expect work fixed filtering json prepare post assigning properties related closed https github api api issues
combined_text: API incompatible with setup_postdata Hello, Using this API and setting up the results with `setup_postdata()` again in another WordPress site creates incompatibility issues on the following properties: `post_author` versus `author` `post_date` versus `date` `post_content` versus `content` `post_title` versus `title` This means that `the_title()`, `the_content()`, etc will not work anymore. I can understand the desire to change these ancient property names to something that makes sense but it breaks compatibility with very standard WordPress functions which most people expect to work. We fixed our problem by filtering `json_prepare_post` and assigning the properties. Related closed issue. https://github.com/WP-API/WP-API/issues/41

title: Getting Parent Post / Comment but not doing anything with it
description: It seems like there was an intention to populate the `parent` field of a comment with the actual parent object (post for top-level comments and comment for child comments), however the `$fields['parent']` value gets overwritten at the end with the `$comment->comment_parent` which I think is the logical thing to put in the `parent` field anyways. Can we have all the parent object info go into a `parent_object` field or some other name that's not `parent` or do we rip this code out altogether? [lib/class-wp-json-response.php:1570-1589](/WP-API/WP-API/blob/master/lib/class-wp-json-posts.php#L1570-1589)  php // Post if ( 'single'  $context ) { $parent = get_post( $post['post_parent'], ARRAY_A ); $fields['parent'] = $this->prepare_post( $parent, 'single-parent' ); } // Parent if ( ( 'single'  $context || 'single-parent'  $context ) && (int) $comment->comment_parent ) { $parent_fields = array( 'meta' ); if ( $context  'single' ) { $parent_fields[] = 'comment'; } $parent = get_comment( $post['post_parent'] ); $fields['parent'] = $this->prepare_comment( $parent, $parent_fields, 'single-parent' ); } // Parent $fields['parent'] = (int) $comment->comment_parent;
text_for_topic_modeling: getting parent post comment anything seems like intention populate parent field comment actual parent object post top level comments comment child comments however fields parent value gets overwritten end comment comment parent think logical thing put parent field anyways parent object parent object field name parent rip altogether class json response php api api blob class json posts php php post single context parent get post post post parent array fields parent prepare post parent single parent parent single context single parent context int comment comment parent parent fields array meta context single parent fields comment parent get comment post post parent fields parent prepare comment parent parent fields single parent parent fields parent int comment comment parent
combined_text: Getting Parent Post / Comment but not doing anything with it It seems like there was an intention to populate the `parent` field of a comment with the actual parent object (post for top-level comments and comment for child comments), however the `$fields['parent']` value gets overwritten at the end with the `$comment->comment_parent` which I think is the logical thing to put in the `parent` field anyways. Can we have all the parent object info go into a `parent_object` field or some other name that's not `parent` or do we rip this code out altogether? [lib/class-wp-json-response.php:1570-1589](/WP-API/WP-API/blob/master/lib/class-wp-json-posts.php#L1570-1589)  php // Post if ( 'single'  $context ) { $parent = get_post( $post['post_parent'], ARRAY_A ); $fields['parent'] = $this->prepare_post( $parent, 'single-parent' ); } // Parent if ( ( 'single'  $context || 'single-parent'  $context ) && (int) $comment->comment_parent ) { $parent_fields = array( 'meta' ); if ( $context  'single' ) { $parent_fields[] = 'comment'; } $parent = get_comment( $post['post_parent'] ); $fields['parent'] = $this->prepare_comment( $parent, $parent_fields, 'single-parent' ); } // Parent $fields['parent'] = (int) $comment->comment_parent;

title: /wp/v2/taxonomies object returns JSON array (not object) on invalid query
description: `/wp/v2/taxonomies?type=wingding` will yield `[]`, when the default response for the endpoint is a keyed object. I presume that the object returned from the API should be consistently formed, so I raise whether we should return `{}` instead if an invalid type property is provided (or whether a descriptive error should be returned instead).
text_for_topic_modeling: taxonomies object returns json array object invalid query taxonomies type wingding yield default response endpoint keyed object presume object returned api consistently formed raise whether return instead invalid type property provided whether descriptive returned instead
combined_text: /wp/v2/taxonomies object returns JSON array (not object) on invalid query `/wp/v2/taxonomies?type=wingding` will yield `[]`, when the default response for the endpoint is a keyed object. I presume that the object returned from the API should be consistently formed, so I raise whether we should return `{}` instead if an invalid type property is provided (or whether a descriptive error should be returned instead).

title: Post query returns json_invalid_query for valid query
description: If you do a query that happens to have no results (e.g. `cat=2` where the category has no posts), you get back a 404 and a `json_invalid_query` error. This should just be an empty JSON list, and not an error.

combined_text: Post query returns json_invalid_query for valid query If you do a query that happens to have no results (e.g. `cat=2` where the category has no posts), you get back a 404 and a `json_invalid_query` error. This should just be an empty JSON list, and not an error.

title: Fix comment schema; return error when response data doesn't match schema
description: In #955, @rmccue was able to change the response format for a comment without updating the schema. The API shouldn't ever return a response that doesn't match the declared schema. In this issue, we should: 1. Fix the schema, somewhat contingent on #1022 2. Return a 500 error when the produced response doesn't match the schema, instead of a malformed object. Note for the second, I'm just referring to fields in the response that are missing or of a different format than in the declared schema. Additional fields can be ignored.
text_for_topic_modeling: comment schema return response data match schema rmccue able response format comment without updating schema api ever return response match declared schema schema somewhat contingent return produced response match schema instead malformed object note second referring fields response missing different format declared schema additional fields ignored
combined_text: Fix comment schema; return error when response data doesn't match schema In #955, @rmccue was able to change the response format for a comment without updating the schema. The API shouldn't ever return a response that doesn't match the declared schema. In this issue, we should: 1. Fix the schema, somewhat contingent on #1022 2. Return a 500 error when the produced response doesn't match the schema, instead of a malformed object. Note for the second, I'm just referring to fields in the response that are missing or of a different format than in the declared schema. Additional fields can be ignored.

title: Using term filters can cause the API to return objects instead of arrays
description: Hi, WordPress allows you to filter processes like get_terms. Through this you can unset terms from the array that's then returned for further processing. A side effect of doing this that affects the JSON encoder but not normally further PHP processing is that the JSON encoder must now output arrays filtered in this way as JSON objects instead of arrays, because the internal structure of the array is now key/value due to deleted numeric keys (wrong terminology, but it sort of works). An example of the problem is here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5943149/rebase-array-keys-after-unsetting-elements Should the API: a) defensively call array_values on things it expects to be trying to output as an array? (So that the API contract can't be broken), or: b) should this be documented behaviour and it's the responsibility of the filter developer to call array_values? I might suggest (a), if only because there may be plugins out in the world that do not call array_values because it's never affected PHP, but being used on sites that then would have potentially random WP-API behaviour switching between Object and Array for filtered and non-filtered term arrays. This probably isn't restricted to term filters, but it's where I noted the behaviour.
text_for_topic_modeling: term filters cause api return objects instead arrays wordpress allows filter processes like get terms unset terms array returned processing side effect affects json encoder normally php processing json encoder must output arrays filtered way json objects instead arrays internal structure array key value due deleted numeric keys wrong terminology sort works example http stackoverflow questions rebase array keys unsetting elements api defensively call array values things expects trying output array api contract broken documented behaviour responsibility filter developer call array values might suggest may plugins world call array values never affected php used sites would potentially random api behaviour switching object array filtered non filtered term arrays probably restricted term filters noted behaviour
combined_text: Using term filters can cause the API to return objects instead of arrays Hi, WordPress allows you to filter processes like get_terms. Through this you can unset terms from the array that's then returned for further processing. A side effect of doing this that affects the JSON encoder but not normally further PHP processing is that the JSON encoder must now output arrays filtered in this way as JSON objects instead of arrays, because the internal structure of the array is now key/value due to deleted numeric keys (wrong terminology, but it sort of works). An example of the problem is here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5943149/rebase-array-keys-after-unsetting-elements Should the API: a) defensively call array_values on things it expects to be trying to output as an array? (So that the API contract can't be broken), or: b) should this be documented behaviour and it's the responsibility of the filter developer to call array_values? I might suggest (a), if only because there may be plugins out in the world that do not call array_values because it's never affected PHP, but being used on sites that then would have potentially random WP-API behaviour switching between Object and Array for filtered and non-filtered term arrays. This probably isn't restricted to term filters, but it's where I noted the behaviour.

title: Media meta sizes has inconsistent data type
description: If a media object does not have any size metadata available, the response value is an empty array (`[]`). If it does have values, then the response value is a dictionary (`{ thumbnail: {  },  }`). For the empty case it should probably instead return an empty dictionary to simplify the deserialization logic for clients.
text_for_topic_modeling: media meta sizes inconsistent data type media object size metadata available response value empty array values response value dictionary thumbnail empty case probably instead return empty dictionary simplify deserialization logic clients
combined_text: Media meta sizes has inconsistent data type If a media object does not have any size metadata available, the response value is an empty array (`[]`). If it does have values, then the response value is a dictionary (`{ thumbnail: {  },  }`). For the empty case it should probably instead return an empty dictionary to simplify the deserialization logic for clients.

title: Required parameter check for user update is in wrong place
description: We currently check for the required parameters (`username`, `password`, `email`) on update, not creation. This should be flipped.
text_for_topic_modeling: required parameter check user wrong place currently check required parameters username password email creation flipped
combined_text: Required parameter check for user update is in wrong place We currently check for the required parameters (`username`, `password`, `email`) on update, not creation. This should be flipped.

title: Only include Post data on the response object when declared in schema
description: This is what our code path looks like currently:  setup_postdata( $post ); // Base fields for every post. $data = array( 'id' => $post->ID, 'date' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_date_gmt, $post->post_date ), 'date_gmt' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_date_gmt ), 'guid' => array( /** This filter is documented in wp-includes/post-template.php */ 'rendered' => apply_filters( 'get_the_guid', $post->guid ), 'raw' => $post->guid, ), 'modified' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_modified_gmt, $post->post_modified ), 'modified_gmt' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_modified_gmt ), 'password' => $post->post_password, 'slug' => $post->post_name, 'status' => $post->post_status, 'type' => $post->post_type, 'link' => get_permalink( $post->ID ), ); $schema = $this->get_item_schema(); if ( ! empty( $schema['properties']['title'] ) ) { $data['title'] = array( 'raw' => $post->post_title, 'rendered' => get_the_title( $post->ID ), ); }  If I remove `title` as a property from the schema, it's not included in the response. However, if I remove `password` from schema properties, it's still included on the response object. I'd expect the response object would only have fields declared in the schema, or at least that WP REST API wouldn't blindly add database data to the response if was purposefully removed from the schema.
text_for_topic_modeling: include post data response object declared schema path looks like currently setup postdata post base fields every post data array post date prepare date response post post date gmt post post date date gmt prepare date response post post date gmt guid array filter documented includes post template php rendered apply filters get guid post guid raw post guid modified prepare date response post post modified gmt post post modified modified gmt prepare date response post post modified gmt password post post password slug post post name status post post status type post post type link get permalink post schema get item schema empty schema properties title data title array raw post post title rendered get title post title property schema included response however password schema properties still included response object expect response object would fields declared schema least rest api blindly database data response purposefully removed schema
combined_text: Only include Post data on the response object when declared in schema This is what our code path looks like currently:  setup_postdata( $post ); // Base fields for every post. $data = array( 'id' => $post->ID, 'date' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_date_gmt, $post->post_date ), 'date_gmt' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_date_gmt ), 'guid' => array( /** This filter is documented in wp-includes/post-template.php */ 'rendered' => apply_filters( 'get_the_guid', $post->guid ), 'raw' => $post->guid, ), 'modified' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_modified_gmt, $post->post_modified ), 'modified_gmt' => $this->prepare_date_response( $post->post_modified_gmt ), 'password' => $post->post_password, 'slug' => $post->post_name, 'status' => $post->post_status, 'type' => $post->post_type, 'link' => get_permalink( $post->ID ), ); $schema = $this->get_item_schema(); if ( ! empty( $schema['properties']['title'] ) ) { $data['title'] = array( 'raw' => $post->post_title, 'rendered' => get_the_title( $post->ID ), ); }  If I remove `title` as a property from the schema, it's not included in the response. However, if I remove `password` from schema properties, it's still included on the response object. I'd expect the response object would only have fields declared in the schema, or at least that WP REST API wouldn't blindly add database data to the response if was purposefully removed from the schema.

title: The response from creating or updating a User should pass context = edit
description: When returning the User response from `WP_JSON_Users_Controller->create_item()` or `WP_JSON_Users_Controller->update_item()` the edit context should be passed. This:  $response = $this->get_item( array( 'id' => $user_id ) );  Becomes:  $response = $this->get_item( array( 'id' => $user_id, 'context' => 'edit', ) );
text_for_topic_modeling: response creating updating user pass context edit returning user response json users controller create item json users controller item edit context passed response get item array user becomes response get item array user context edit
combined_text: The response from creating or updating a User should pass context = edit When returning the User response from `WP_JSON_Users_Controller->create_item()` or `WP_JSON_Users_Controller->update_item()` the edit context should be passed. This:  $response = $this->get_item( array( 'id' => $user_id ) );  Becomes:  $response = $this->get_item( array( 'id' => $user_id, 'context' => 'edit', ) );

title: Raw data goes unused when sent to an endpoint.
description: In class-wp-json-server.php, when dispatching callbacks if an endpoint expects raw data that data will end up going unused breaking the endpoint:  php elseif ( $supported & self::ACCEPT_RAW ) { $data = $this->get_raw_data(); }

title: "registered_date" type is "date-time"
description: the schema on wp/v2/users returns: "registered_date": { "description": "Registration date for the resource.", "type": "date-time", "context": [ "edit" ], "readonly": true }, according to json-schema v4 "type": "date-time" is NOT a valid type and it brakes parsers. it should be "string" with "format":"date-time" ref: http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-core.html#anchor8 http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-validation.html#anchor107 example: "registered_date": { "description": "Registration date for the resource.", "type": "string", "format": "date-time", "context": [ "edit" ], "readonly": true },
text_for_topic_modeling: registered date type date time schema users returns registered date description registration date resource type date time context edit readonly true according json schema type date time valid type brakes parsers string format date time ref http json schema latest json schema core html anchor http json schema latest json schema validation html anchor example registered date description registration date resource type string format date time context edit readonly true
combined_text: "registered_date" type is "date-time" the schema on wp/v2/users returns: "registered_date": { "description": "Registration date for the resource.", "type": "date-time", "context": [ "edit" ], "readonly": true }, according to json-schema v4 "type": "date-time" is NOT a valid type and it brakes parsers. it should be "string" with "format":"date-time" ref: http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-core.html#anchor8 http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-validation.html#anchor107 example: "registered_date": { "description": "Registration date for the resource.", "type": "string", "format": "date-time", "context": [ "edit" ], "readonly": true },

title: Boolean request args fail validation
description: In rest_validate_request_arg() we cannot use the `! is_bool()` conditional to validate if a request argument is either `true` or `false`. The query string in the url (example: https://demo.wp-api.org/wp-json/wp/v2/categories?hide_empty=true) will be parsed as a string. Which means you will always get the error: { code: "rest_invalid_param", message: "Invalid parameter(s): hide_empty", data: { status: 400, params: { hide_empty: "hide_empty is not of type boolean" } } }
text_for_topic_modeling: boolean args fail validation rest validate arg cannot use bool conditional validate argument either true false query string url example https demo api json categories hide empty true parsed string means always get rest invalid param message invalid parameter hide empty data status params hide empty hide empty type boolean
combined_text: Boolean request args fail validation In rest_validate_request_arg() we cannot use the `! is_bool()` conditional to validate if a request argument is either `true` or `false`. The query string in the url (example: https://demo.wp-api.org/wp-json/wp/v2/categories?hide_empty=true) will be parsed as a string. Which means you will always get the error: { code: "rest_invalid_param", message: "Invalid parameter(s): hide_empty", data: { status: 400, params: { hide_empty: "hide_empty is not of type boolean" } } }

title: Inconsistent type returned for user capabilities.
description: When a WP user has capabilities and a call is made to `/users/:id?context=edit`, a JSON object/map is returned (`"capabilities": {"a":"foo", "b":"bar"}`). However, when a user has no capabilities (`- No role for this site -` selected in wp-admin), an empty array is returned (`"capabilities": []`).
patched_file_types: other-file | test-file | other-file | other-file | other-file | other-file | other-file | test-file | test-file | documentation-file | other-file | test-file
text_for_topic_modeling: inconsistent type returned user capabilities user capabilities call made users context edit json object map returned capabilities foo bar however user capabilities role site selected admin empty array returned capabilities
combined_text: Inconsistent type returned for user capabilities. When a WP user has capabilities and a call is made to `/users/:id?context=edit`, a JSON object/map is returned (`"capabilities": {"a":"foo", "b":"bar"}`). However, when a user has no capabilities (`- No role for this site -` selected in wp-admin), an empty array is returned (`"capabilities": []`).

title: Standardize the expected POST/PUT properties expected for schema nested objects
description: In the [Posts Controller we accept POST/PUT values for `title` and `content` to be sent as `title.raw` or `content.raw`](https://github.com/WP-API/WP-API/blob/develop/lib/endpoints/class-wp-rest-posts-controller.php#L782). In this controller, we do NOT have a `santization_callback` set on the top-level `title` or `content` properties in the schema. The way the Comments Controller is setup prevents being able to pass `content.raw` to set the comment_content [because we DO have a sanitization_callback set on the top level `content` property](https://github.com/WP-API/WP-API/blob/develop/lib/endpoints/class-wp-rest-comments-controller.php#L867) in the schema. This means attempting to create or update a comment with `content.raw` set results in the following error: > stripslashes() expects parameter 1 to be string, array given Some questions that need answering: 1. Do we want to limit the acceptable parameters for the nested objects? Examples: - only accept `content` and ignore `content.raw` values - only accept `content.raw` and ignore `content` values 2. Do we want to accept both top-level and `.raw` property values for the nested objects? 3. How can we modify the schema (if needed) to apply callbacks or required parameters to nested objects?
text_for_topic_modeling: standardize expected post put properties expected schema nested objects posts controller accept post put values title content sent title raw content raw https github api api blob develop endpoints class rest posts controller php controller santization callback set top level title content properties schema way comments controller setup prevents able pass content raw set comment content sanitization callback set top level content property https github api api blob develop endpoints class rest comments controller php schema means attempting create comment content raw set results following stripslashes expects parameter string array given questions need answering want limit acceptable parameters nested objects examples accept content ignore content raw values accept content raw ignore content values want accept top level raw property values nested objects modify schema needed apply callbacks required parameters nested objects
combined_text: Standardize the expected POST/PUT properties expected for schema nested objects In the [Posts Controller we accept POST/PUT values for `title` and `content` to be sent as `title.raw` or `content.raw`](https://github.com/WP-API/WP-API/blob/develop/lib/endpoints/class-wp-rest-posts-controller.php#L782). In this controller, we do NOT have a `santization_callback` set on the top-level `title` or `content` properties in the schema. The way the Comments Controller is setup prevents being able to pass `content.raw` to set the comment_content [because we DO have a sanitization_callback set on the top level `content` property](https://github.com/WP-API/WP-API/blob/develop/lib/endpoints/class-wp-rest-comments-controller.php#L867) in the schema. This means attempting to create or update a comment with `content.raw` set results in the following error: > stripslashes() expects parameter 1 to be string, array given Some questions that need answering: 1. Do we want to limit the acceptable parameters for the nested objects? Examples: - only accept `content` and ignore `content.raw` values - only accept `content.raw` and ignore `content` values 2. Do we want to accept both top-level and `.raw` property values for the nested objects? 3. How can we modify the schema (if needed) to apply callbacks or required parameters to nested objects?

title: Approving a comment deletes content and author
description: _Bug:_ Changing comment status from hold to approved using a PUT request deletes the comment author and comment content. I am using the basic auth plugin and an $http request in AngularJS. _How to replicate:_ Add an unapproved comment to your site with the WP API v2 and basic auth plugins installed. Using Postman, send a PUT request with a basic auth header to a comment endpoint, such as mysite.com/wp-json/wp/v2/comments/54 In the form data, send along status=approved. The comment will be approved, but the comment author and comment content are deleted.
text_for_topic_modeling: approving comment deletes content bug changing comment status hold approved put deletes comment comment content basic auth plugin http angularjs replicate unapproved comment site api basic auth plugins installed postman send put basic auth header comment endpoint mysite json comments form data send along status approved comment approved comment comment content deleted
combined_text: Approving a comment deletes content and author _Bug:_ Changing comment status from hold to approved using a PUT request deletes the comment author and comment content. I am using the basic auth plugin and an $http request in AngularJS. _How to replicate:_ Add an unapproved comment to your site with the WP API v2 and basic auth plugins installed. Using Postman, send a PUT request with a basic auth header to a comment endpoint, such as mysite.com/wp-json/wp/v2/comments/54 In the form data, send along status=approved. The comment will be approved, but the comment author and comment content are deleted.
